Optimal perfusion of the gastric tube can be assessed by indocyanine green fluorescence-angiography (ICG-FA). We evaluated whether locating the anastomosis in a zone enhanced within 60 s after ICG-FA injection reduced severe anastomotic leakage (Stage 2 or 3) within 30 days after esophagectomy. Methods ICG-FA was assessed in 69 patients and compared to 122 control patients undergoing minimally invasive Ivor Lewis esophagectomy. Whenever possible, the anastomosis was placed on gastric tissue enhanced within 60 s after ICG-FA injection, with resection of the gastric tip if needed. Results Severe anastomotic leakage occurred in 8.4% of cases, with 6 cases of anastomotic leakage (8.7%) in the ICG-FA group and 10 (8.2%) in the non-ICG-FA group ( p Conclusion Our results were not statistically significant, possibly due to a lack of power. There was no trend indicating a decrease in anastomotic leakage using our ICG-FA method, therefore other studies must help determine an optimal quantitative ICG-FA method to reduce postoperative morbidity after esophagectomy. A near infrared camera shows ICG-FA tissue perfusion only seconds after injection [ 13 14 18 19 p 20 Another method using fluorescence-intensity curves requires complex software and calculations, and there is no precise cut-off value. [ 19 21 An easy quantitative ICG-FA method time of blood perfusion from peripheral IV (intravenous) injection to the gastric tip. In a 2018 prospective cohort published by Kumagai and al. of 70 patients, anastomosis was made on tissue showing blood flow within 60 s after ICG injection, and non-perfused tissue after 90 s was resected. Rate of AL was low (1,4%) with mean gastric perfusion time of 35 s. Three AL occurred in tissue perfused after 60 s, whereas no AL occurred in tissue perfused within 60 s [ 22 A 2017 retrospective cohort by Ohi and al. involving 120 patients showed decrease of AL rate when using ICG-FA with correction of poor perfusion within 60 s (1,7% versus 14,7%, HR 9 ( p The aim of this study is to assess quantitative ICG-FA with a time-to-perfusion cut-off of 60 s after injection to reduce AL in Ivor Lewis esophagectomy at the Bordeaux University Hospital. Methods This “before and after” cohort study was conducted in the esogastric surgical department of the University Hospital in Bordeaux, France. Inclusion criteria All consecutive patients who underwent minimally invasive Ivor Lewis esophagectomy for a mid-low or gastroesophageal junction tumor, by laparoscopic and thoracoscopic approach with intrathoracic esophagogastric anastomosis, in our surgical department from 2018 to 2021 (with use of ICG-FA starting March 2020). Non-inclusion criteria Patients with cervical esophagogastric anastomosis, open surgery, pregnancy, age under 18, and missing data concerning the ICG-FA, were not included. ICG-FA protocol After stapling of the gastric tube, 0,1 mg/kg of ICG was injected intravenously and flushed with 10 ml of 0,9%. NaCl. Gastric tube perfusion was assessed 60 s after injection using a SPY laparoscopic camera device (PINPOINT system), placed in the optical port. Images at 60 s (Image 1 2 Image 1 Satisfactory blood perfusion reaching the tip of the gastric tube. Oesogastric surgical department, Bordeaux University Hospital Image 2 Unsatisfactory blood perfusion of the tip of the gastric tube, with transition level identified by 3–0 PDS marking stitch. Oesogastric surgical department, Bordeaux University Hospital End-to-side or end-to-end handsewn interrupted esophagogastric anastomosis was performed by a right axillary mini-thoracotomy. The gastric tip could be resected following macroscopic and ICG-FA perfusion assessment. Anastomosis was done at the level of the marking stitch, if possible, with recording of distances between gastric tip, marking stitch and anastomotic site. Endoscopic or radiologic exams were performed when postoperative complications were suspected. Primary outcome The primary outcome was defined as AL stage 2 or 3 (requiring endoscopic or surgical treatment), within 30 days after surgery, diagnosed clinically (sepsis, mediastinitis, purulent discharge in drain), radiologically (leak of contrast product, air bubbles, abscess on CT scan with IV and ingested contrast product or upper gastro-intestinal series) or endoscopically (anastomotic opening, tissue defect or necrosis). We recorded other postoperative outcomes including morbimortality, pulmonary complications, and length of stay. Statistical analysis Patients in the ICG-FA group were compared with the non ICG-FA group using a Chi- square test with a p value of less than 0.05 considered statistically significant. Statistical analysis was performed using R software. Ethical approval Anonymized data was collected using computed patient files and the surgical department database. Our study was approved by the Bordeaux University Hospital Ethics Committee. Results 191 patients were included from January 2018 to March 2021. ICG-FA was used in 69 (36%) of patients. 1 patient was excluded because surgery was done by open approach to remove liver lesions. This led to change in strategy in 8 patients, with gastric tip resection in 7 patients and change of anastomotic site in one patient. None presented with AL. Discussion Our cohort study comparing postoperative outcomes and change in surgical strategy before and after using ICG-FA during Ivor Lewis esophagectomy did not find statistically significant results. However, our 60-s threshold involved change in esophagogastric anastomotic site in one third of patients, without change in AL rate. ICG-FA and AL 6 patients presented with AL in the ICG-FA group. One patient with transition level had no change in surgical strategy, and AL may have been avoided. 3 patients with AL had satisfactory ICG-FA, but macroscopic tissue quality was also optimal, so there was no possibility to foresee AL. In these cases, AL may have been caused by factors other than ischemia, such as technical difficulties, inflammatory tissue, or anastomotic tension. 2 patients presented with AL despite resection of the gastric tip, but one leakage was at mid height of the gastric tube due to thermal injury, without necrosis, and could not have been prevented by ICG-FA. Efforts were made to make the anastomosis on the marking stitch but this was not always possible due to insufficient gastric tube length, resulting in AL in one case where anastomosis was made 2 cm above the marking stitch. The other four patients with placement of anastomosis above the marking stitch did, however, not present AL. Several studies suggest that surgical corrections according to ICG-FA can reduce AL. In a literature review with 1186 patients, Daele and al. found a significant decrease in AL from 20.5% to 9.9% when using ICG-FA ( p p 2 p 23 The gastric tip being supplied by the microvascular mucosal and submucosal blood network [ 24 25 ICG-FA can also be used during the thoracic approach [ 26 28 29 Sakuma and al. evaluated correlation between ICG-FA results and endoscopic results at postoperative day 1 in 86 patients. Their only significant correlation was between ICG-FA results and congestive mucosa in endoscopy, which suggests that ICG-FA may be a better indicator of veinous congestion rather than poor arterial blood supply [ 30 Our AL rate was relatively low (8,4%), and reduction of this rate, even with use of ICG-FA, is difficult to achieve. This may explain our non-significant results. ICG-FA and other measures such as preoperative nutrition may contribute to the aggregation of marginal gains, for incremental reduction of anastomotic leak. Quantitative use of ICG-FA Our 60-s threshold was chosen according to literature [ 13 22 31 33 p 34 35 In Kumagai and al’s “90-s-rule” study [ 22 22 32 p 36 37 Yamamoto and al. conducted a retrospective review of 97 cases, with 12 postoperative leakages. The ICG-FA videos enabled creation of time-intensity curves, showing a trend towards slower intensity in the cases with anastomotic leakage. However these results were not significant [ 38 Several software tools are emerging to enable a better, objective use of ICG-FA, as shown by Nijssen and al. who compared two different software algorithms, using fluorescence time curves. However, this study showed differences in measurement (mean relative difference + 58.2%), without significant relationship with AL. This underlines the extent of the technical possibilities of IGC use, but with a lack in standardization making its interpretation difficult [ 39 Strengths Our study has methodological strength as it was conducted in a high-volume center, with standardized surgical technique. Our ICG-FA protocol is simple, precise and easy to use in common surgical practice. Limitations Our study was not randomized, however both study groups had similar characteristics. Absence of randomization also provides real-world data with better external validity. Our « before and after» cohort design induces historical bias, as therapeutic care improves over time, reducing postoperative morbidity. We therefore included patients since 2018, after our unit had 3 years of experience in minimally invasive surgery. Furthermore, despite ICG-FA results, choice of anastomotic site was left to the surgeon’s discretion. Poor ICG-FA was not corrected in 13% of cases, reflecting real-life situations. Perspectives Large, randomized studies are needed to confirm these retrospective results, exploring different quantitative ICG-FA measures such as colorimetric measurements [ 16 19 21 40 41 42 36 It is also questionable whether IGC-FA is the best method to assess gastric perfusion, as shown by Haruta and al. who compared ICG-FA and multispectral camera on 30 cases. ICG-FA was assessed quantitively as time in luminance increase. AL occurred in 100% of patients considered with poor vascularization in multispectral camera, versus 60% with poor ICG-FA results [ 43 Conclusion Our quantitative ICG-FA protocol influenced our decision of anastomotic site during minimally invasive Ivor Lewis, but has not led to significant reduction in AL rate when applied in a center with a low AL rate (8,4%). Therefore, the use of ICG-FA does not diminish AL rate in high-volume, specialized centers with AL rates within international benchmarks. Further studies may help determine whether ICG-FA proves more useful in low-volume centers.
